docs.lead_paragraph: The Mets, Keith Hernandez said, ''have to take our off-day tomorrow, retreat, dig in and come out fighting.'' But have they already, in only two games of the World Series, dug themselves such a hole that they won't be able to fight their way out of it? ''Kansas City was in the same boat last year,'' Hernandez noted, ''and they won.'' But has the Mets' boat sprung so many leaks that they cannot keep it from sinking?

docs.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. MRS. R. R. M. CARPENTER Jr. is the only person, living or dead, who suffered through a World Series with her husband and now, 30 years later, is suffering through another with her son. She is the wife of Bob Carpenter, chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Phillies, who lost the baseball championship of North America to the Yankees in four games in 1950, and the mother of Ruly Carpenter, president of the club that leads the 1980 tournament with the Kansas City Royals, two games to none. Has it been an ordeal? ''An ordeal?'' Mrs. Carpenter said. ''Yes, and worst of all was Houston.'' In Houston last weekend, the champions of the National League came clawing, scratching, cutting and slashing from behind to win the third pennant in the club's 98-year history, twice in extra innings, and always in wildly improbable fashion.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT took the Phillies 98 years to win a World Series, and when they did, it was worth more than ever before - $34,693.18 a man. At $32,211.95 a share, the Kansas City Royals set a record, too, by collecting the sweetest purse ever paid to losers. There is poetic justice in the fact that the club that waited longest received the biggest reward, but it is dead wrong. There is no justification today for the antiquated system of paying World Series players out of receipts for the first four games. It is unfair that the Yankees' left fielder, say, should receive more when his team wins the championship than the Boston shortstop gets when the Red Sox win, just because Yankee Stadium holds more customers than Fenway Park. With millions from television guaranteed, there is no reason why baseball should not fix the size of the winners' and losers' shares, as professional football does, and establish individual qualifying rules.

headline.main: To the Victors Belong What Spoils?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Detroit Tigers have traded Willie Horton, their 33-year-old former All-Star left fielder, to the Texas Rangers. Details of the deal were held up since Horton, with more than 10 years in the major leagues and five years with the same club, had the power to nullify the agreement. But Horton said yesterday that he wouldn't veto the deal.

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE man dropped out of a tree and set out to earn his meat with a bludgeon of mountain ash, no manager of a baseball team ever fired himself for unsatisfactory work, until the other day. ''Did you ever hear,'' Gene Mauch was asked, ''of a manager resigning because he wasn't satisfied with the way he was doing his job?''

headline.main: Mauch, a Manager Who Fired Himself

docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA ON Oct. 3, 1951, Bobby Thomson hit The Home Run, and the game will always be remembered for that. It was the third and last match in the pennant playoff between the New York Giants and Brooklyn Dodgers. In the last of the ninth inning, Brooklyn led, 4-2, with one out and two Giants on base. Then Thomson hit a baseball into the seats beyond left field and got it all for the Giants in one piece, 5-4. It will always be Bobby Thomson's game, yet it could have been described as the story of two third basemen. Billy Cox of the Dodgers was Brooks Robinson, Clete Boyer and Pie Traynor rolled into one that day. Everything the Giants hit toward his side of the infield became an out in his sure hands.
